title: Every 3 hit proc has a visual stack indicator except for Brand's
body:
{{champion:161}}  has a visual indicator on his targets of how many stacks they have of his passive. {{champion:91}} just got one. {{champion:245}} {{champion:85}} {{champion:203}} {{champion:223}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:201}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:29}} {{champion:254}}  all have some way to look at a target and see at a glance how many times they've been struck, so they can judge when their 3 hit proc is going to happen. 

Edit: And {{champion:427}} 's Daisy. And {{champion:150}} .

During the mage update, {{champion:63}}  joined the elite ranks of champions with a 3 hit proc passive, but has no visual indicator, even though his proc is extremely important to his play, both in lane and during teamfights. We can only see if a target is burning or not, we have no indication of how many stacks of burning they have. 

I have included an extremely detailed example of how this may look, for Riot's viewing pleasure. 

http://i.imgur.com/1lKnLrV.png

Just want to say that "proc" means programmed random occurrence, and 3 hit passives are not random. A proc would be getting a crit with less than 100% crit chance.

From the [League wiki](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/League_of_Legends_terminology):
> **Proc**
> The activation of an effect.

> [{quoted}](name=Morcleon,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=YEEhvgbn,comment-id=00070000,timestamp=2016-11-28T18:16:04.390+0000)
>
> From the [League wiki](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/League_of_Legends_terminology):

from the actual definition:
programmed random occurrence
Proc is an acronym for a programmed random occurrence that refers to a weapon, item or ability activating with the "Chance on Hit" or "Chance on Use" effect (an ability or a spell).

You're defining a League term with an actual definition and a bunch more league terms.  "on hit" in the dictionary does not mean the same thing as in the game.  Same with ability, spell, weapon, passive, critical strike.

> [{quoted}](name=6Sfool,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=YEEhvgbn,comment-id=0007000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-28T23:11:01.062+0000)
>
> You're defining a League term with an actual definition and a bunch more league terms.  "on hit" in the dictionary does not mean the same thing as in the game.  Same with ability, spell, weapon, passive, critical strike.

But "proc" is not an actual LoL term like ability or critical strike. It's just a random thing people started saying.

I don't love the word proc, but it's convenient as opposed to activate.  If there's a better word for it that I can type in-game I don't know about it.  While the actual meaning is pretty obscure, you do have a point.

> [{quoted}](name=Thezanman,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=YEEhvgbn,comment-id=000700000000,timestamp=2016-11-28T23:05:54.606+0000)
>
> from the actual definition:
> programmed random occurrence
> Proc is an acronym for a programmed random occurrence that refers to a weapon, item or ability activating with the "Chance on Hit" or "Chance on Use" effect (an ability or a spell).

Actual definitions do not correspond with the League definitions as we can clearly tell in game. There is no "random occurrence" with skills such as Silver Bolts or Z-Drive Resonance. Once they are activated by 3 stacks, they activate.

Meaning follows usage. It's how language evolves.
